I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area 
(BIMP-EAGA) cooperation initiative was formally launched in 1994 as a joint strategy of the 
participating  governments  to  address  the  social  and  economic  development  of  their  less-
developed  and  more  remote  territories.  Following  early  gains,  cooperation  development  in 
BIMP-EAGA was disrupted by the 1997 Asian financial crisis. As the economies recovered, 
regional leaders at the seventh Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) summit in 
November 2001 supported the revitalization of the BIMP-EAGA cooperation initiative. Between 
2002  and  2003,  BIMP-EAGA  reassessed  its  strategies  and  implemented  structural  and 
institutional reforms to strengthen its consultations and dialogue mechanisms. In 2004, with the 
help of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other development partners,1 BIMP-EAGA 
began the process of developing a new road map to chart the subregion’s economic and 
cooperation development for the following 5 years. At their second summit in Kuala Lumpur in 
December  2005,  the  leaders  approved  for  implementation  the  BIMP-EAGA  Road  Map  to 
Development (2006–2010).  
 
2.  The road map has guided the prioritization of the subregion’s cooperation initiatives in 
the last 2 years. At the fourth summit in November 2007, the leaders supported the decision of 
the ministers and senior officials to conduct a comprehensive midterm review of the road map to 
ensure that the measures being implemented remain relevant and fully support the goals of 
BIMP-EAGA and that targets will be achieved in a timely manner. The leaders also reiterated 
the ministers’ and senior officials’ request for ADB to support the review process. 
 
3.  BIMP-EAGA is one of two2 subregional cooperation initiatives in archipelagic Southeast 
Asia  that  ADB  supports.  As  BIMP-EAGA’s  regional  development  advisor,  ADB  has  been 
providing assistance to key BIMP-EAGA initiatives. The proposed regional technical assistance 
(RETA) will give ADB the means to enhance its role by ensuring the accelerated implementation 
of the BIMP-EAGA road map within a results-focused framework.3 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The  subnational  area 4  comprising  BIMP-EAGA  share  the  similar  challenge  of 
considerable  geographic  distance  from  their  country's  core  economic  regions.  They  are 
resource-rich island economies that are less developed than the capital regions. BIMP-EAGA 
was created at a time of prosperity for the participating countries, encouraging the governments 
to undertake activities to narrow in-country development gaps and ensure that the benefits of 
economic  growth  accrue  to  the  more  remote  territories.  Taking  advantage  of  the  physical 
proximity, cultural affinity, and long history of trade between the EAGA component areas, a 
cooperative strategy was adopted to increase cross-border trade, tourism, and investments, and 
promote  the  integration  of  the  economies  of  the  subregion.  Cooperation  in  this  area  was 
envisioned to be private sector-led and market driven.  
                                                 
1  Including the ASEAN Secretariat and Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ, the German 
Agency for Technical Cooperation), that provided the BIMP Facilitation Center with technical assistance. 
2  The other subregional cooperation initiative is the Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle. 
3  The RETA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 27 March 2008. 
4  The focal subnational areas of BIMP-EAGA are (i) the provinces of Kalimantan, Maluku, Papua, and Sulawesi, in 
Indonesia; (ii) the states of Sabah and Sarawak and the federal territory of Labuan in Malaysia; and (iii) Mindanao 
and Palawan in the Philippines. Brunei Darussalam is a full state member of EAGA. The member countries use the 
term BIMP-EAGA (or simply EAGA) to refer to the subregional cooperation initiative and the geographic subregion.

2   
 
5.  The strong commitment and support of the government leaders to immediately identify 
and address the structural impediments to growth in the EAGA made early gains possible. 
Between 1994 and 1997, national policies were modified and cooperative agreements were 
facilitated to ensure the success of the cooperation initiative. Among other things, transport 
policies and travel regulations were relaxed, resulting in improved subregional connectivity and 
increased cross-border movement of people and goods. Business, cultural, and social networks 
within the subregion expanded and joint-venture investments in agribusiness, tourism, and 
trading  increased.  The  1997  financial  crisis,  however,  disrupted  early  plans  and  progress 
slowed. In the immediate aftermath of the crisis, the private sector businesses which were 
initially expected to play the leading role had to retrench staff. Governments were forced to 
focus on the most urgent nationwide macroeconomic and structural challenges and had little 
financial  capacity  to  support  regional  programs.  Public  sector  investments  in  regional 
infrastructure declined severely, resulting in the further slowdown in the implementation of key 
EAGA development initiatives.  
 
6.  Growth  in  the  region  resumed  in  late  2001  and  regional  leaders  supported  the 
revitalization and repositioning of the EAGA. ADB technical assistance played a helpful role in 
these  efforts. 5  This  renewed  interest  in  the  EAGA  cooperation  initiative  was  an 
acknowledgement  of  the  vital  role  subregional  cooperation  could  play  in  sustaining  the 
economic  recovery  of  the  EAGA;  however,  it  was  also  aimed  at  supporting  the  broader 
integration goal of ASEAN. This, along with new challenges arising from a significantly changed 
regional  and  global  economic  environment,  led  the  EAGA  to  reassess  its  approach  to 
cooperation development. As part of the economic integration efforts, the leaders declared 
BIMP-EAGA a test-bed for the implementation of regional agreements and, more recently, as an 
important  economic  corridor  in  ASEAN.  To  initialize  the  revitalization  efforts,  the  EAGA 
implemented important structural reforms, starting with the reprioritization of the sectors for 
cooperation. The creation of a subregional central secretariat—the BIMP Facilitation Center 
(BIMP-FC) — was another major step taken to ensure continuity of the regional cooperation 
effort through the effective monitoring and coordination of cooperation activities among EAGA 
institutions and stakeholders as well as with development partners. Another measure included 
the restructuring of the private sector umbrella organization, the BIMP-EAGA Business Council 
(BEBC). In 2004, the ninth ministerial meeting approved the preparation of a broad-based 
development road map to chart BIMP-EAGA’s cooperation activities over the next 5 years. In 
2005, the EAGA leaders approved for implementation the new development road map that is 
focused  on  enhancing  the  subregion’s  competitive  advantage  through  cross-border 
consolidation, complementation, industry clustering, and value-chain management. 
 
7.  As embodied in its development road map, the ultimate goal of BIMP-EAGA is to narrow 
the development gap across and within the EAGA member countries. Road map targets6 were 
established alongside its four pillars of (i) promoting intra- and extra-EAGA trade, investments,

3
and tourism in selected priority sectors (namely agro-industry and natural resources, transport, 
infrastructure,  and  information  and  communication  technology)  with  particular emphasis  on 
small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development  in  these  sectors;  (ii)  coordinating  the 
management  of  natural  resources  for  sustainable  development  of  the  subregion;  (iii) 
coordinating the planning and implementation of infrastructure support to economic integration, 
with active participation of the private sector; and (iv) strengthening the BIMP-EAGA institutional 
structures and mechanisms for effective implementation of the EAGA road map and action plan.  
 
8.  The road map has guided the direction of cooperation activities in BIMP-EAGA in the 
last 2 years. The EAGA leaders at their fourth summit expressed encouragement over the 
steady progress in the implementation of the road map. They noted in particular the signing of 
three landmark subregional transport agreements7 aimed at facilitating cross-border air, sea, 
and land connectivity. In conjunction with the transport agreements, measures to harmonize 
border formalities were set in motion in 2007.8 These efforts are a major step forward in 
accelerating  economic  integration  and  realizing  EAGA’s  long-term  goal  of  establishing  the 
subregion as a single production base and tourism destination. BIMP-EAGA countries have also 
intensified  cooperation  in  environmental  management  and  biodiversity  conservation.  The 
countries have signed cooperation agreements, such as the Heart of Borneo Initiative and the 
Sulu Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion, that aim to establish networks of protected forests and marine 
resources through international cooperation led by the governments and supported by a global 
effort.  Other  major  accomplishments  of  BIMP-EAGA  include  (i)  actively  re-engaging  local 
governments  in  cooperation  development,  (ii)  implementing  a  communications  strategy 
involving the subregion’s private sector media, (iii) adopting a structured project development 
process and results-based project monitoring and evaluation framework, and (iv) introducing 
subregional value chains for priority commodities.   
 
9.  While accomplishments have been significant, performance of the different sectors has 
been  uneven.  Prioritization  and  implementation  of  projects  under  the  natural  resource 
development sector has met with difficulties. Participating countries tend to continue protecting 
their competitive advantage in key industries—such as oil palm, seaweeds, fisheries, and agro-
industry—thereby  threatening  the  efficient  establishment  of  subregional  value  chains. 
Implementation of some flagship projects has been delayed by the lack of funding for needed 
sectoral assessments, especially in areas affecting private sector investments. Thus the private 
sector response to public sector actions has been weak in almost all sectors except tourism. 
Moreover, enterprise development in EAGA continues to be constrained by the lack of effective 
access by small and medium-sized enterprises to equity and credit financing.  
 
10.  EAGA officials anticipated that these issues would affect the timely implementation of 
the road map and the realization of the goals and targets. Hence, the senior officials agreed to 
conduct a review of the road map programs and projects to ensure that they are contributing to 
the realization of the goals of the subregion. There was a strongly articulated need to determine 
if the programs and projects embodied in the development road map remain relevant and 
effective in meeting the current and emerging challenges and opportunities facing BIMP-EAGA

the need to confirm that cooperation structures and mechanisms adequately facilitate and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact of the RETA is to help accelerate the implementation of the road map. This 
will involve determining the progress of implementation to date in relation to the road map 
targets.  Implementation  issues  and  potential  constraints  will  be  identified  and  solutions 
formulated to address them. The outcome will be more focused and results-oriented action 
plans that will directly contribute to achieving the road map goals and targets.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The RETA will focus on helping BIMP-EAGA achieve the two-fold objectives of the 
midterm review. The main objective will be to (i) comprehensively take stock of the progress 
achieved and the results realized in the implementation of the road map; (ii) identify the various 
issues and challenges facing the implementation of the BIMP-EAGA road map; (iii) identify the 
priorities that BIMP-EAGA should pursue in the remaining period of the road map (2008–2010) 
to  achieve  the  road  map  goals,  including  the  accelerated  increase  of  trade,  tourism,  and 
investments;  (iv)  determine  if  the  current  institutional  structures  and  mechanisms  are 
appropriate and are facilitating or constraining the accelerated implementation of the road map; 
and  (v)  recommend  changes  or  adjustments to  the  road  map  as  warranted.  A  secondary 
objective of the midterm review is to identify future priorities that BIMP-EAGA might pursue in 
the next 5 years (2009–2013) based on emerging opportunities in the various sectors. To the 
extent possible, the RETA will endeavor to provide a quantitative assessment of the road map 
accomplishments, even as it acknowledges the difficulties in obtaining updated disaggregated 
statistics on trade, tourism, and investments for the component areas of the subregion.  
 
13.  As agreed with the BIMP-EAGA senior officials, the midterm review process will be 
undertaken by the stakeholders themselves with ADB providing technical guidance and expert 
advice. The senior officials emphasized the need for the active participation of the clusters,9 
working groups, and the private sector in the review process. This is to ensure their ownership 
of, and responsibility and accountability for, the results of the performance assessment and the 
subsequent midterm review report to be presented to the BIMP-EAGA leaders at the fifth 
summit  in  Thailand  in  December  2008.  The  BIMP  FC  will  lead  the  review  process  in 
coordination and collaboration with the different national secretariats, clusters, and working 
groups.  
 
14.  A lead facilitator will work closely with the head of the BIMP FC in reviewing relevant 
documents and reports including agreed action plans, and in designing the midterm review 
workshops and other consultation activities. The lead facilitator will formulate a scorecard and 
identify the quantitative and qualitative parameters for objective assessment of the performance 
                                                 
9  Clustering the working groups was part of the structural reform of 2001–2003, when the 11 working groups were 
grouped into four clusters that now represent the priority areas for development in EAGA as follows: (i) transport, 
infrastructure, and information and communication technology; (ii) natural resources; (iii) tourism; and (iv) small and

5
and contribution of the individual clusters and working groups in realizing the goals of the BIMP-
EAGA road map.  
 
15.  Sector experts will be engaged to prepare an assessment of the growth prospects of 
priority industries (e.g., transport and trade logistics, agro-industry, fisheries, and tourism) and 
the potential competitive advantage of BIMP-EAGA in these industries. Based on their findings, 
the experts will recommend actions to be adopted by the clusters and working groups to 
enhance EAGA’s competitiveness in these industries. The sector experts will present their 
findings and recommendations during the workshops, which will serve as additional guides for 
reprioritizing  and  refining  the  activities  and  target  deliverables  of  the  clusters  and  working 
groups. 
 
16.  Focused group discussions and other consultation activities with such stakeholders as 
the Local Government Unit Forum, the BEBC, and the BIMP-EAGA Tourism Council will be 
conducted to supplement the review made by the clusters and working groups. This is to obtain 
a broader view of the aspirations and expectations of how the BIMP-EAGA cooperation initiative 
can be best utilized to promote economic development and poverty reduction in the subregion.  
 
17.  A midterm review task force will be created to function as the core group to review and 
discuss the preliminary reports, paying particular attention to the cross-cutting goals of the road 
map not falling under any specific cluster or working group. The task force will be composed of 
(i) the country chairs of the four clusters, (ii) the national secretariats, (iii) the head of the BIMP-
EAGA FC, and (iv) the executive vice chairman of the BEBC. A consolidation workshop will 
review the final draft of the midterm review report.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $300,000 to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB's TA (technical assistance) funding program. The RETA cost estimates and budget are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
19.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, responsible for implementation and 
monitoring in consultation with the BIMP-EAGA member countries. A no-objection letter will be 
obtained before starting the RETA activities in the territory of the participating member countries. 
Implementation and monitoring of the RETA will be done in close consultation with the BIMP 
Facilitation Center and the midterm review task force. 
 
20.  The RETA will finance about 37 person-months of consultant services (18 international 
and 19 national), including sector experts who will conduct the sector assessment studies. The 
consultants will be hired as individuals and will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The consultants’ 
outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB will be actively involved in implementing the 
technical assistance, including the conduct of workshops facilitated by the RETA, and ADB staff 
will be used as resource persons when appropriate. 
 
21.  The RETA implementation period is from April to December 2008.

6   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  for  the  Comprehensive  Midterm  Review  of  the  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–
Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area Road Map to Development, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
1.  Individual consultants will be engaged to provide advice and technical assistance 
for a total of 16 person-months of international consulting services and 19 person-
months of national consulting services as outlined below.  
A.  Lead Facilitator (international, 8 person-months)  
 
2.   The lead facilitator should be familiar with the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–
Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA) and its mechanisms 
and will work closely with the head of the BIMP Facilitation Center in carrying out the 
following duties. 
  
(i)  Organize the midterm review task force and agree on a work program 
and schedules.  
 
(ii)  Review relevant documents and reports and undertake (a) initial stock 
taking of the progress achieved and results realized in the implementation 
of the BIMP-EAGA Road Map to Development and its related action plan 
as well as the action plans of the clusters and working groups, and (b) 
identification  of  the  various  issues  and  challenges  facing  the 
implementation of the road map.  
 
(iii)  Develop  appropriate  quantitative  and  qualitative  parameters  and 
scorecards to ensure that the review of performance and assessment of 
progress achieved is comprehensive, objective, and pragmatic.  
 
(iv)  Design, implement, and facilitate the midterm review workshops of the 
clusters  and  working  groups  to  ensure  optimum  participation  of  the 
stakeholders in the review and assessment of the subregion performance 
vis-à-vis the goals and targets of the road map and generate ownership of, 
and responsibility and accountability for, the midterm review results by the 
stakeholders. 
 
(v)  Design,  implement,  and  facilitate  consultations  and  focused  group 
discussions with other selected stakeholders—such as industry and trade 
groups, local governments, and national secretariats—with the objective 
of  (a)  supplementing/validating  the  review  made  by  the  clusters  and 
working groups, and (b) obtaining a broader view of the aspirations and 
expectations  of  how  BIMP-EAGA  cooperation  can  be  best  utilized  to 
promote economic development and poverty reduction in the subregion.  
 
(vi)  Identify  and  facilitate  the  engagement  of  sector  experts,  including (a) 
preparing specific terms of reference for each expert, (b) supervising the 
effective participation of sector experts in the midterm review process, 
and (c) ensuring the timely delivery of sector studies and assessments, 
and facilitate the consideration by BIMP-EAGA of the recommendations 
made by the experts.  
 
(vii)  Facilitate  the  work  of  the  researcher/statistician  in  gathering  and 
collecting  disaggregated  statistics  on  BIMP-EAGA  trade,  tourism,  and

B.   Sector Experts (five international, 10 person-months combined)  
 
3.  Overall, the responsibilities will be as described below. More specific terms of 
reference will be prepared as the sector experts are engaged. 
(i)  (a) Conduct an assessment of the potential for development of the BIMP-
EAGA priority sectors, (b) determine the competitiveness and competitive 
advantage of BIMP-EAGA in these sectors, and (c) identify the most 
pressing  challenges  and/or  constraints  to  the  development  of  these 
sectors. 
 
(ii)  Recommend actions to address the issues and/or constraints and to take 
advantage of the opportunities.  
 
(iii)  Facilitate  the  discussion,  endorsement,  and  adoption  of  the  studies’ 
results and recommendations by the countries.  
 
 
C.   Researcher/Statistician (national, 3 person-months) 
 
4.  The responsibilities will include the following. 
 
(i)  Gather and compile disaggregated statistics for the subnational territories 
of  BIMP-EAGA  and  for  Brunei  Darussalam  on  trade,  tourism,  and 
investments and other parameters as may be required by the road map 
review including overall regional economic performance and cross-border 
activities. 
 
(ii)  Analyze and evaluate the performance of the subregion as shown by the 
statistics.

12       Appendix 3 
 
D.  Project Secretariat (two national, 16 person-months combined) 
5.  The consultants, located at the BIMP Facilitation Center office at Kota Kinabalu, 
Sabah, Malaysia, will have the following responsibilities. 
  (i)  Provide  analytical  support  in  preparing  briefing  papers  and  other 
documents  including  the  status  reports  on  the  implementation  of  the 
development road map and flagship and priority subregional projects. 
  (ii)   Help  in  consolidating  the  reports  of  the  review  workshops  and  other 
consultation meetings and in preparing all draft reports and final reports 
as may be required. 
(iii)  Help  organize  secretariat  support  including  (a)  prepare  draft 
correspondence,  (b)  identify  and  negotiate  conference  venues  for 
consultations and meetings, and (c) provide overall logistical support for 
technical  assistance  project  activities  including  field  requirements  of 
consultants. 
(iv)  Assist in coordinating with national secretariats, cluster heads, and the 
BIMP-EAGA Business Council the implementation of midterm review 
activities.  
(v)  Participate in Asian Development Bank missions as required.
